chunk_summary: Salmonella Typhi invades the intestinal mucosa, survives intracellularly, and disseminates systemically, causing prolonged fever, systemic symptoms, and intestinal damage. Early antibiotic treatment reduces complications and mortality.
learning_objectives: Understand the pathogenesis of typhoid and enteric fever, including Salmonella Typhi's survival mechanisms.
Identify the clinical progression and complications of untreated typhoid fever.
Recognize the importance of early antibiotic intervention in reducing mortality and complications.
Learn the role of the Vi capsular antigen in immune evasion and disease progression.
key_facts: Salmonella Typhi survives gastric acidity and invades Peyer’s patches in the terminal ileum.
Incubation period is typically 1-2 weeks but varies with inoculum size and host factors.
Secondary bacteremia drives prolonged fever and systemic symptoms.
Vi capsular antigen reduces opsonization and dampens early intestinal inflammation.
Untreated disease can lead to intestinal ulceration, bleeding, or perforation in the second to third week.
Chronic carriage is rare in children but significant for outbreak propagation.
reference_quote: Salmonella Typhi expresses a Vi capsular antigen that reduces opsonization and dampens early intestinal inflammation, contributing to the insidious onset. (StatPearls, NCBI Bookshelf)
